19. To keep them from conflicting.
For example, the lakes support many clear blues,
and the smalts support white lakes;
clear massicot can sit well next to green.
Let ash-white can be shadowed with brownish yellow,
purple, with blue or red, and, indeed, let the different
half-tints be enhanced with clear ones.
Here one must try a variety of ways.
right-middleObserve colors in order to make reflections.

20. Sometimes large flat panels of cloth
look beautiful worn by stately Men;
sometimes one sees this also on the hoods of Monks.
where two folds of fabric overlap
one another, whether stretched or relaxed.
Further, on occasion, do not exclude
some modern costumes which are
in use nowadays, or worn in the past.
right-middleBeautiful large panels of Silk, with here and there a gleaming fold, have a fine look, as do Monksâ€™ hoods and modern clothes.

21. What further should I indicate to you?
Where you should, with bold intelligence,
lace up, slash, or loop edges, collars, slips,
and hems hanging halfway to the knee?
Make facings, trimmings, braids, and buttons,
tied up here, open there, over and under Clothes,
chemises and laces; cloaks, veils,
and a thousand elegant fabrications?

22. Test, seek, and invent, observe the work of others,
pick up something as you design;
temper, transform, seek to combine
what you can bring to good form.
Make this your goal. And, for good drapery,
prepare your first layer well and add glazes,
which will help it achieve a shining transparency,
for making Velvets and beautiful Satins.

23. While you achieve elevation in Fabrics
by highlighting all the folds,
it is quite different with Velvets.
Indeed, you make everything dark, and only
make only smooth highlights on the edges of the folds.
But as regards the coloring of any silk Satins,
I can offer you no more bountiful Example
Than life, which is the Master of every Painter.
right-middleOf Velvets and silk.

div.ab:
24. One sees various styles of Fabrics
in the work of great Masters:
Raphael of Urbino worked wonders here,
and considered his folds after the proper custom.
Some Figures are dressed quite simply, some richly;
